I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  People’s  Republic  of  Bangladesh  for  the  Strengthening  Governance  Management 
Project.  The  report  also  describes  the  proposed  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  Supporting 
Governance Management Project, and if the Board approves the proposed loan, I, acting under 
the authority delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA. 
 
The project seeks to improve transparency and accountability of public service delivery 
2. 
in  tax  and  land  record  administrations  in  Bangladesh  with  the  help  of  information  and 
communication  technology  (ICT).  The  three  outputs  of  the  project  are  (i)  online  filing  of  tax 
returns,  (ii)  digitized  land  records  management  system  in  selected  districts,  and  (iii)  improved 
access to tax and land information in specialized information and service centers.1 
 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

A. 
 
Despite  persistent  poverty, 2 Bangladesh  is  on  track  to  achieve  the  2015  Millennium 
3. 
Development  Goal  target  of  reducing  income  poverty  by  half,  has  made  progress  in  other 
indicators of well-being (such as for infant and child mortality), and has met the target for gender 
parity in primary and secondary schooling. While some progress has been made in alleviating 
poverty  (e.g.,  during  2000–2005,  income  poverty  was  reduced  from  48.9%  to  40%,  or  by  1.8 
percentage points annually), income inequalities widened, especially in the 1990s, and poverty 
reduction has been uneven across regions (with the urban areas not seeing great reduction in 
poverty).  It  does  not  help  that  the  country  has  a  rather  limited  resource  base,  especially  from 
direct  taxes,  from  which  to  augment  public  investment  in  economic  and  social  infrastructure. 
The income tax to gross domestic product (GDP) ratio in Bangladesh is hovering around 2%, as 
against 4% in Pakistan and more than 6% in India. 
 
4. 
Compounding  this  problem  is  the  lack  of  good  governance  in  the  country.  For  five 
consecutive  years  from  2001  to  2005,  Bangladesh  was  placed  at  the  bottom  of  the  list  in 
Transparency International's corruption perceptions index.3 Other universal indices (such as the 
Global  Integrity  Report,  Doing  Business  Survey)  and  national  surveys  (such  as  the  state  of 
governance) also consistently show that there is still much progress to be made in governance 
reforms,  and  in  ensuring  that  the  average  citizen  perceives  that  the  state  provides  effective, 
transparent, and accountable public services.  
 
5. 
It  is  now  universally  recognized  that  good  governance  can  help  a  country  to  improve 
allocative  efficiency  of  limited  resources. While  macro  policy-based  reforms  are  necessary

conditions for good governance,4 the conditions need to be commensurate with the changes in 
the  delivery  mechanism,  supported  by  state-of-the-art  technologies.  ICT  applications  have  the 
potential  to  trigger  and  shape  significant  changes  in  the  delivery  of  public  services  and  in  the 
way  governments  function.  The  ruling  party's  own  election  manifesto  and  the  Government's 
Digital  Bangladesh  strategy  acknowledge  this.  In  this  regard,  as  in  many  other  developing 
countries,  the  Government  has  promoted  e-governance  applications  in  recent  years  to  foster 
growth and development and to enhance the quality of service delivery.  
 
The project is consistent with the country partnership strategy 5and is in conformity with 
6. 
the recommendations made in the 2009 country assistance program evaluation in Bangladesh, 
which  found  that  lack  of  good  governance  in  many  areas  is  one  of  the  country's  binding 
constraints  on  growth,  and  recommended  support  for  further  governance  reforms.6 The  Asian 
Development Bank’s (ADB’s) country operations business plan for 2010–2012 for Bangladesh7 
states that ADB will continue to provide assistance in improving governance in Bangladesh by 
enhancing governance management capacity. Recognizing the need for the application of ICT 
tools for improved governance, the Supporting Governance Management Project identifies three 
key  areas  where  the  application  of  ICT  tools  has  the  potential  to  enhance  efficiency, 
transparency, and accountability in public service delivery: 
 

(i) 

 
(ii) 

Tax  administration  is  one  of  the  most  promising  areas  where  good  governance 
can lead to significant gains in terms of increasing tax revenues and in enhancing 
transparency in tax filing. Indeed, a country's tax policy is in many ways only as 
good  as  the  supporting  tax  administration.8 It  is  widely  accepted  that  filing  tax 
returns  online  can  significantly  improve  tax  compliance  and  revenue  buoyancy. 
Electronic  tax  filing  is  one  example  of  how  automation  can  assist  in  facilitating 
processing of tax files.9 Another benefit of electronic tax filing is the elimination of 
the  interface  between  the  taxpayer  and  tax  officer,  thereby  reducing  the 
incidence of corruption and other alleged fraudulent practices. 

Proper  land  records  management  is  another  area  where  the  application  of  ICT 
tools  can  greatly  enhance  the  quality  of  public  service  delivery.  Digitization  of 
land  records  is  one  of  the  important  prerequisites  for  improvements  in  land-
related  services  and good  administration that  also  aim to  reduce  harassment  of 
the  average  landowner  and  small  business  owner  in  registering  property.  In  an 
agriculture-dependent  economy  where  marginalized 
landholding  by  small 
farmers is a defining characteristic, maintaining land records is a precondition not 
only  for  land  reform  policies  to  be  successfully  implemented  but  also  for  social

3 

justice. Moreover, Bangladesh is one of the most crowded countries in the world 
and  competition  for  land  is  fierce.  As  such,  and  because  of  forged  ownership 
records,  disputes  over  land  ownership  are  the  biggest  single  cause  of  court 
cases in Bangladesh. It has been reported that land disputes can take anywhere 
from 3 years to 45 years to be resolved.10 It has also been reported that almost 
80% of legal battles (criminal cases) in Bangladesh are about land (the number is 
expected to be even higher in civil cases). Given that court cases (both civil and 
criminal)  can  be  a  major  source  of  harassment  to  the  poor,  it  makes  business 
sense to try to alleviate the primary cause of the case, i.e., inaccurate records of 
land holdings. The use of ICT in land records management enables accelerated 
storage,  processing,  and  retrieval  of  information  in  land  records.  Digitization  of 
land records can also help to generate revenue, since proper land records help 
the government to raise significantly higher revenue from land. 

The  success  of  any  good  governance  initiative—based  on  the  principle  of  a 
participatory  approach—critically  depends  on  equal  access  to  information,  and 
bidirectional information flows. Good governance principles alone cannot help to 
alleviate poverty without equal and easy access to all relevant information for the 
citizenry.11 Weak  and  inadequate  information  infrastructure  systems,  as  well  as 
limited financial resources to develop or strengthen them, could easily derail the 
good  governance  initiatives.  The  advent  of  ICT  tools  through  the  designated 
information  centers  makes  equal  access  to  information  possible  even  in  the 
remote  villages,  provided  these  centers  are  effectively  designed  and  properly 
managed.  Thus,  the  information  centers  could  benefit  the  communities  and  the 
government in many ways, including by: (a) saving on costs of compliance with 
government  rules  and  procedures,  (b)  reducing  harassment  by  middlemen,  (c) 
providing  additional  information  to  make  the  good  governance  initiatives 
successful, and (d) helping the government to accomplish the desired outcomes 
of  the  proposed  good  governance  initiatives.  However,  considerable  efforts  are 
needed  to  address  the  information  constraints  and  difficulties  with  financial  and 
technical  support.12 Research  has  shown  that  the  benefit  on  investment  from  a 
telecenter can be high. Thus, supporting the government's endeavor to promote 
information sharing is important to achieving the overall impact of the project.13

 Impact and Outcome 

Overarching  the  support  in  these  three  areas  is  the  project  focus  on  capacity  building. 
7. 
Improved  business  processes  and  public  service  delivery  cannot  be  implemented  and 
maintained unless capacity development is an integral part of the new initiatives. Therefore, the 
project seeks to build the capacity of government staff members concerned, including those of 
the executing agencies. 
 
B. 
 
The  intended  impact  of  the  project  will  be  enhanced  public  trust  in  central  government 
8. 
for service delivery. The project outcome will be improved transparency and accountability in tax 
and  land  record  administrations. Its focus  on  e-governance  at  the  local  level  is  important  as  it 
carries  forward  the  policy-based  reforms  of  the  ongoing  Good  Governance  Program  (footnote 
2).  The  project  will  be  spread  over  45  upazilas  in  five  districts,  in  relation  to  land  records 
digitization,  and  in  20  information  and  service  centers  throughout  the  country,  in  relation  to 
access to tax information.14 
 
C. 
 
9. 
 

The project will have three outputs: 

Outputs 

Output 1: Online filing of tax returns. The areas that will be targeted here are 
(a) online filing of tax returns by designing the software, and (b) strengthening the 
ICT capacity of the income tax circles.15  

Output 2: Digitized land records management system in selected districts. 
The  project  will  help  pilot  a  digitized  land  records  management  system  in  45 
upazilas (subdistricts) of five districts in phases, with necessary corrections in the 
project implementation strategy. The activities will include (a) digitizing text data, 
(b)  digitizing  cadastral  paper  maps,  and  (c)  linking  all  spatial  and  text files. The 
project will develop a web-based database of (a) land records in five districts and 
45  upazilas,  and  (b)  the  particulars  of  any  plot  of  land  including  its  map  and 
records of rights in the selected districts and upazilas.   

Output  3:  Improved  access  to  tax  and  land  information  in  specialized 
information  and  service  centers.  The  project  will  help  design,  set  up,  and 
manage  (a)  20  tax  information  and  service  centers  at  the  major  income  tax 
circles (including one at the National Board of Revenue office in Dhaka), and (b) 
20  land  information  and  service  centers  in  the  selected  upazilas  out  of  45 
upazilas selected for digitized land record management system. The activities will 
include (a) creating an effective design for these centers, (b) procuring computer 
hardware,  (c)  planning  and  designing  the  information  and  service  contents  of 
these centers,16 and (d) recruiting customer service associates to manage these 
centers for a limited period.

Implementation Arrangements 
 
13. 
There  will  be  two  project  executing  agencies  for  the  project.  The  National  Board  of 
Revenue (NBR) will be the executing agency for outputs 1 and 3a and the Department of Land 
Records and Survey (DLRS) will be the executing agency for outputs 2 and 3b. Each executing 
agency  shall  incorporate  a  dedicated  project  management  unit  (PMU).  A  project  steering 
committee (PSC) will be established to provide overall direction and guidance to—and oversight 
and monitoring of—the project. The secretary, Ministry of Land will chair the committee, which 
will  include  one  senior  official  at  the  level  of  a  joint  secretary  of  the  relevant  ministries  and 
agencies. Two separate PMUs will be set-up—one at NBR for outputs 1 and 3a,18 and the other 
at DLRS for outputs 2 and 3b. The PMUs will be headed by a senior level government official 
not below the rank of a joint secretary as the project director, who will report to the PSC.

III. 

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 

 
15. 
Improvements  in  business  processes  and  public  service  delivery  cannot  be  achieved 
and maintained unless capacity building is an integral part of the new initiatives. Therefore, the 
project will also focus on building the capacity of government officials concerned, including staff 
of  the  executing  agencies  and  implementing  agencies.  Thus,  it  is  proposed  that  the  TA  for 
Supporting  Governance  Management  Project  be  approved  and  provided  in  tandem  with  the 
Strengthening Governance Management Project in order to provide support to the government 
to  enhance  the  capability  of  the  relevant  agencies  to  effectively  manage  the  project.  The  TA 
project  will  enhance  staff  members'  familiarization  with  rules  and  processes  and  help  them  to 
implement  the  loan  components.  All  procurement  in  the  TA  project  will  be  managed  in 
accordance  with  ADB's  Procurement  Guidelines  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  No 
advance procurement or advance action is envisaged for the TA project. Capacity building will 
include the following three outputs  corresponding to the three project outputs: 
 

Output  1:  Project  implementation  support;  preparing  the  income  tax  audit 
manual  and  training;  setting  up  the  research  capacity  of  the  National  Board  of 
Revenue,  including  training  on  techniques  related  to  revenue  forecasts  and 
compliance costs; and other training.19 

Output  2:  Creating  adequate  capacity  in  the  PMUs  to  implement  the  proposed 
activities.  This  will  require  hiring  long-term  consultants  (project  implementation 
expert and information technology expert) and training government staff.

16. 
The  total  cost  of  the  TA  project  is  estimated  at  $980,000  equivalent.  ADB  will  finance 
$800,000  on  a  grant  basis  from  its  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-IV)  to  be 
administered  by  ADB.  The  remaining  $180,000  equivalent  will  be  contributed  by  the 
government,  and  will  include  counterpart  staff  remuneration,  office  accommodation  and 
supplies, local transport, and other logistical support.  
 
17. 
The implementation arrangements for the TA project will mimic those of the loan project. 
The TA project components will be implemented by the relevant PMUs, with overall supervision 
by  the  PSC  and  coordination  by  the  PMU  (paras.  12–13).  A  total  of  139  person-months  of 
consultancy  services  will  be  required,  including  6  person-months  of  international  consultant 
services  and  133  person-months  of  national  consultant  services.20 A  consulting  firm  will  be 
engaged  for  recruiting  the  national  consultants  using  the  quality  and  cost-based  selection 
method with a standard quality–cost ratio of 80:20. All consultants will be recruited in line with 
ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). No advance 
contracting  or  retroactive  financing  is  envisaged  for  consulting  services.  All  disbursements 
under  the  TA  will  be  made  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).21

IV. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

Technical 

A. 
 
18. 
Outputs  1  and  2  of  the  loan  project  have  technical  components  at  their  core. 
Strengthened  tax  administration  is  expected  to  be  brought  about  through  the  introduction  of 
online  tax  filing  software  that  has  been  tested  and  standardized.  The  software  will  be 
customized to fit the Bangladesh context. Digitization of land records is to be done through an 
industry  standard  as  well  as  one  adopted  by  other governments.22 Some  customization  of  this 
application  is  expected.  Positive  impacts  of  the  introduction  of  technology  include  speedier 
processes,  and  so  reduced  compliance  costs.  There  are  no  expected  negative  impacts  as  a 
result  of  introducing  the  technologies.  Capacity  building  support  in  the  project  will  help 
government departments better manage the required technical operations. 
 
B. 
 
19. 
Financial  analysis  performed  on  the  proposed  project  concluded  that  its  benefits 
considerably  outweigh  the  costs. 23  The  financial  viability  and  sustainability  analysis  of  the 
project was based on main financial parameters and sensitivity analysis, and on a with-project 
and  without-project  scenario,  using  the  financial  internal  rate  of  return  calculation  on  the  net 
benefits  accruing  from  project  implementation.  The  sensitivity  analysis  also  demonstrated  the 
robustness of these results, with the project being financially viable even when the combination 
of  changed  assumptions  in  a  worst-case  scenario  was  tested.  Comparisons  of  the  project 
benefits  were  also  made  against  the  weighted  cost  of  capital.  The  economic  benefits  of  the 
project are harder to calculate as they are not easily quantifiable. In this context, the least-cost 
approach  was  followed  while  designing  the  project  components  to  ensure  that  the  benefits  of 
the project are most efficiently derived from the investment in this project.24  

Economic and Financial 

 
Governance 

C. 
 
20. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  government.  The  specific  project  requirements  and  supplementary  measures  are 
described in the PAM. 
 
21. 
A  governance  risk  assessment  of  public  financial  management,  procurement,  and 
corruption was carried out. While public expenditure and financial accountability assessment for 
Bangladesh  shows  some  systemic  weaknesses  in  the  public  financial  management  domain, 
these are not expected to constrain effective project implementation. Governance weakness in 
the area of procurement primarily arises from the fact that the Government has not necessarily 
adhered to some provisions in the Procurement Act in the recent past,25 and this has meant that 
governance  weaknesses  in  this  area  need  to  be  more  diligently  tracked,  and  national 
competitive bidding should follow the ADB guidelines. While there have been substantial policy 
reforms related to the fight against corruption, recent steps to weaken the independence of the

D. 
 
The  poverty  reduction  and  social  impacts  of  the  project  are  very  positive,  although  not 
22. 
very direct.26 Enabling online tax filing and easy and accurate access to land records will reduce 
the  scope  for  human  interaction  with  government  officials,  thus  reducing  the  scope  for 
demanding illicit extra payments for services. This is expected to reduce the degree of hairani 
(harassment) of the average citizen and business owner. Stemming the revenue losses inherent 
in the existing system of tax filing and improving the tax auditing ability  of the government will 
mean  increased  direct  revenues  for  the  government.  These,  in  turn,  become  available  for 
productive  social  and  economic  infrastructure.  There  are  no  adverse  social  impacts  (such  as 
HIV/AIDS,  human  trafficking,  etc.)  of  the  project.  Moreover,  sex-disaggregated  data  on  land 
ownership  and  taxpayers  will  help  future  advocacy  on  gender-targeted  policy  reforms  in  the 
areas of tax and land registration.

24. 
The  key  risks  in  the  project  are  (i)  a  lack  of  government  commitment,  including 
personnel, to continue with reforms and to allocate resources to implement them; (ii) a low level 
of  capacity  in  central  and  local  government  agencies  to  implement  the  reform  measures;  and 
(iii) an inability or unwillingness of the citizenry to use ICT and the information centers. Overall, 
however, while there are risks, the integrated benefits and impacts of the project are expected 
to  outweigh  the  potential  costs  from  such  risks.  Further  analysis  on  the  risks  and  mitigating 
measures are in the Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan (Appendix 2).
